segments.text: What you want to get down is some of the facts.
You probably in this course of study, you've been there and you've studied a little bit about the history of Vietnam.
Okay, I got my orders to go to Vietnam and left right after New Year's.
And it was cold, it was cold in January in New York.
And I flew from New York to San Francisco and got in there at night to this one particular building in San Francisco International Airport.
Kind of waited around with another 150 other guys that were going to Vietnam.
Some for their second tour and some for their first tour like myself.
Lots of young guys?
Yeah, sure.
Lots of guys my age too by now, like 27, 28.
A lot of career military guys, sergeants, officers.
And this is our job.
We're going to work.
This is what we were trained to do.
This is what we were motivated to do.
that and I believe that today.
Those guys got on that plane, nobody put a gun on them.
I could have resigned my commission at the airport and gone home.
That was my job.
That's what I was trained to do.
That's what I signed on to be.
I got on that plane to San Francisco and it was a commercial airplane with stewardesses and everything.
It was a charter.
Transglobal or something.
It was a charter fleet.
You just like flying TWA or paying them.
They served us the little meals and
We got to fly to Hawaii and we got there very early in the morning to Hawaii.
I remember how Hawaii smelled of flowers.
And we just walked around the airport while we were through the plane.
It was like two o'clock in the morning.
We're going off to war and the airport's deserted.
No brass bands or anything.
We're going to war.
This is in January of 68.
And from there we flew to Hawaii.
It's a little tiny manhole cover out in the middle of the Pacific.
And they were refueling just this Navy installation to refuel the plane there.
Watch the sun come up out of the Pacific.
It's something I'll never forget.
And from there, we flew to right in Vietnam.
I remember the stewardess, we landed at Ben Hoa Epe.
The stewardess says, welcome to Ben Hoa, Vietnam.
Everybody said boo.
Just like welcome to Cincinnati, or welcome to New York, or welcome to San Antonio.
She says, welcome to Ben Hoa, Vietnam.
And she did wish us all good luck in our tours of duty.
And then that same plane would take out another plane load of guys who were rotating back to the States.
We got off the plane, it was during the day, and the first thing that struck you was the enormous heat and humidity and the dust and the smell of Vietnam.
We got in, it was in the evening, they put us, got us some supper.
I forget where we had, so we had something to eat and then crashed.
They had some temporary barracks there for us, just wooden shacks really.
We crashed and had an outdoor latrine in there.
I think it was washed up a little bit.
I knew what, as an officer you had orders directly to a unit, so it was just a matter of hooking up.
The next morning there was a two and a half ton truck and we all going up to division headquarters, 25th Division Headquarters.
And we all threw our gear.
We put some fatigues on.
We had stateside fatigues, not jungle fatigues.
We put some fatigues on, threw the rest of our gear on the back of the truck, and off we went up Highway 1 from Ben Hoa to Cu Chi.
And that was my first exposure to Vietnam.
I was sat in the front.
I was seeing a guy on a truck, so I rode in the front with the driver.
He had an M16 with one clip of ammunition, 18 rounds.
That was the only weapons we had on this truck.
And we just drove up the middle of that road, 25 miles.
at Coochee Divisional Headquarters, just like we were driving down Interstate 35.
I mean, there was a lot of civilians and people running around, and we had to blow the horn a lot to get everybody out of the way.
The driver was a young fellow, enlisted man.
He said, oh, this damn thing's almost over.
What happens?
He'd hide in the hair of Charlie in weeks, months.
Hadn't been mortared or rocketed.
Nobody shot at him.
It's been quiet.
Of course, we didn't know that they were infiltrating and getting ready for that type of offensive.
They were all hiding out in the jungle.
But we drove up to the divisional headquarters, just bigger than Dixie, 20 guys on a truck and one gun.
Anybody want to take us out, they could.
Got to the divisional headquarters, I was assigned to the 2nd Battalion, 14th Infantry as their signal officer.
Well, I drew my gear and an M16 rifle,
sign for some equipment, because as I said, I had to sign for cryptography equipment.
You know what cryptography equipment is?
What that is, is it's automatic coding and decoding machines for communications.
Like a cryptogram.
Yeah, okay, just like that.
And even a battalion that we had, so I had to check everything on the sign for it.
And I had a repair shop that would fix the radios and stuff back at the battalion.

They had taken a brigade up there and made a forward base up there near the Cambodian border, had an air field on it that we had built out of the jungle and that was the big jungle up there and we drove in a convoy and every morning a convoy would leave the division headquarters to go to this base camp and every morning the first people out on the convoy was a company of mechanized infantry because the bad guys would ambush and they'd have to fight their way up the road every morning.
And we were in a cowboy, and that was my first dust, I won't forget the dust in January.
I still have it.
I have a triangular bandage that's part of a first aid kit.
I made a cowboy-style bandana just to keep the dust out.
And I went up there to join the battalion.
We'd get shot at occasionally up there.
I remember the rats up there, huge, as big as dogs.
I was in a foxhole when a rat jumped on my stomach, so we left a little candle on it and the rats didn't like light, but if you put all the lights out in the foxhole, the rats would come in there.
Big rats, huge rats.
Everything was big up there.
They had pythons crawling across the airfield, they had rats as big as, we have, you know, cats here in the house, rats as big as that.
Big.
Mosquitoes.
Hmm?
Mosquitoes were a problem.
No, there probably were no mosquitoes.
Scorpions as big as crawfish.
Yeah, big black scorpion.
But that's, that's not real important.
We got up there and everybody's getting ready for this big truce.
It's gonna have a ceasefire, very intense.
And we're right up near the Cambodian border and we had artillery, we had airfield, we had all sorts of infantry units out there.
I mean, it was a good,
Good place ever.
Now being a Signal Corps guy, we had switchboard and we had radios and we also had a multi-band radio just like you're using here.
You could get everything.
We listened to AFN Saigon.
And that night, first night of the Tet ceasefire, a young soldier came and said, Captain, you need to come on down to Switchboard Bunker and listen to this.
Okay.
So I got out my foxhole and what's going on?
There's AFN.
All you can hear is this guy saying, stay in your BOQs, stay in your barracks.
And you hear gunfire in the background.
You hear airplanes.
And this is on a radio station in Saigon.
We thought it was a joke.
I said, what's going on?
He said, all hell seems to have broke loose in Saigon.
So I got on the brigade.
I called my buddy at the brigade, Sigma.
I said, what the hell is going on?
Because the brigade had more communications with Saigon than we had.
He said, something crazy's going down in Saigon.
We don't know just yet.
So I said, well, I better tell the old man.
I got the colonel up and says, something hit the fan down in Saigon.
I don't know what's going on there.
What the hell?
It's a ceasefire.
There's supposed to be nothing going on there.
Well, it went about an hour later.
You know, this is dead at night.
It's about an hour later.
We finally get the word.
Ceasefire's off.
We start shooting our mortars and artillery starting what they call H&I, harassment and interdicting fire.
by the time, there wasn't a bad guy within 50 miles of us all down around the side-gun area kicking ass.

Well, we stayed up there another couple of days and we got the orders to tear down that base camp and return back to Coochee, to our divisional headquarters, or because of all the things that had happened, it was that big Tet Offensive.
So, yeah, I was in the Tet Offensive, except the bad guys worked right past it.
And we got down to,
the divisional headquarters, which had been kind of like a country club, and that place was torn up.

I mean there were shell holes all over the place, and I had, talking to some of the guys that had been down there, they were feeling sorry for us being on the Cambodian border, and they cut off our help.
Although the Tet Offensive was a military defeat for the enemy, was, it was, wasn't it also a psychological defeat for the United States?
Not, not us.
Every time we came into contact with Charlie, we kicked his ass up.
So the Tet Offensive to you was not a bad sign?
No, we whipped him.
We whipped him.
No, we didn't feel bad.
We just said, geez, what are these people doing here?
Don't they realize they can't do this?
Because every time we would catch him like that, we'd get blown away.
We had such enormous firepower.
So you still felt that the war was winnable after the Tet Offensive?
Did you see it as the tide changing?
Oh, heavens no.
In fact, you know, you're not going to believe this, but we would wish that he would do that more often.
Try to come against us in a big offensive like that.
Come out of those underground tunnel networks.
Come out of the jungle.
Because every time he did that, we would stomp the snot out of him.
You see that?
For every one of our cows, we must have taken 20 of his.
Never mind all this crap you hear about inflated body counts.
I sure am piled up there like cordwood.

They'd go in there, they'd have an initial success against two MPs guarding the front of a PX somewhere, and they'd commit 50 guys, and the next thing you know, we'd gang up on those basses and take them out with a thousand guys.
You understand that?
So, in a guerrilla war, whenever they...
break off the guerrilla war and move to the conventional warfare stage, they got the snot stomped out of them.
They got killed, big time.
You know, there's no way to tell how many of those people we killed during that Tet Offensive, that first one.
No, there's no telling.
But everything, every even small success like up north in
We took everything back.
So do we see that as a turning point in the war?
Yeah, we're saying, gee, if these guys are going to keep this particular strategy up, there's not going to be any soldiers left up north.
You see?
Do you understand that?
And that's the thing that bothers me when I see Walter Crankcase and Dan, whatever his name is, saying this was a turning point.
the defeat of America.
Bullshit.
That's not true.
Do you think it had a lot to do with them being there and showing it on TV?
How important do you think the media was?
Oh, enormous.
You see, those guys communicated to the American people that we had been whipped in Vietnam during the Tet Offensive.
And the American people said, oh my God, this is, oh my, oh, this is so terrible.
Oh,
All our generals are telling us that they went into war and these guys take over the American embassy.
My God.
Stop.
But from a professional soldier standpoint, if those guys would have done it all the time, eventually there would be nobody left because they got such a bad military whipping.
Politically.
Oh, did they win politically?
Everything that they lost, they more than made up for in the streets and on the television sets and newspapers of America.
Think about that.
Their victory in the Tet Offensive wasn't in Vietnam.
It was in Brooklyn and San Francisco and in Temple, Texas, on the streets and in the living rooms of America.
That's where they won.
Because there was such a biased news reporting of Vietnam War.
They didn't talk about the big victory.
They showed the kids getting killed over there.
The kids are talking about the American soldiers.
You see the American guys getting shot at.
Do you think they have a responsibility, the media has, for showing the public, or do you think they should have been kept out of the war?
Well, like in World War II, there was a national effort towards winning the war.
It even existed in the media.
Look at the movies, eye bonds.
Look at the news reporting, the radio broadcasts.
Everything was geared towards the war efforts.
Here, in Vietnam, that wasn't the case.
There was no popular support in the media for a military victory in Vietnam.
Why do you think that?
I can speculate.
Would you like me to speculate?
Sure.
Essentially, those individuals who were professional soldiers were what we would call today conservatives.

Now, John F. Kennedy, Thai conservatives, what was prevalent in the arts, and the media is part of the arts, is kind of a liberal attitude, what we would call liberal today, I don't know what you called it back then, but it was more of a pacifist, accommodate, patronize,
non-violence, roses and sunshine.
If you only love somebody long enough, you'll win them over, all kinds of stuff.
And that filtered down into the media's approach towards the interpretation of the war.
You know, a guy like Walter Cronkite, or a guy like Dan Rather, or a guy like Tom Brokaw, he wasn't...
The inflection that they...
what they show, how they describe it could have a profound effect upon how the American people saw the war.
Just, just an inflection of the war.
Now I didn't, I didn't see all the coverage because I was over there where they're making the movie.
I wasn't back over here.
But the, the general consensus was amongst the professional soldiers of Vietnam is that what got back to us later on after it was over, after we had come back from our tour, is that
The American people were getting kind of a one-sided view of the war, like somehow it was an exercise in futility that we could never defeat these people.
You could never win over there.
It's not true we could.
We had the power to do it.
And nobody likes frustration.
Nobody likes to be frustrated.
Your sons and husbands are going over there and they're getting killed, but not for any real purpose, not for any real good purpose.
So that kind of upsets you.
You're usually going to get tired of hearing about it.
And every night you're seeing some kid getting smoked on TV.
Today in Vietnam, X number of GIs got smoked, and this, that, and chicken.
And living from a couple TVs now, not black and white, with the blood, and the screaming, and the bullets, and the blowing up.
And you're getting this seven days a week.
At six and at ten,
Never mind the newspapers, never mind Time magazine.
That's just where I get right down to the television stuff.
That's the main way that people receive information.
And Living Color, I mean, today in Vietnam, when I had the footage, it wasn't six months ago, and it wasn't censored by the government.
Guys, whatever, you know, old Vietnam, you'd be surprised.
I was a signal officer, right?
So I was always hanging around with the Chinese headquarters.
So I was a newsman around, doing something.
After a while, you get tired of it.
What kind of biased piece of reporting are you going to do today?
You just want to give us a break.
So yeah, did the media have a profound effect on the eventual disposition of the conflict in Vietnam?
It was the controlling factor.
I call it the media war, if you want to call it that.
Do you think they had a right to do that, or do you think they were out of... Oh, they sure had a right to do it.
Do you think they were out of line?
Do you think that they... No, I think those people were being honest to themselves, but I think they have a distorted view of what was going on over there.
So you do agree that they should have been over there?
Should have been over there.
Because, see, this thing had never really elevated itself to a real war, and if it had been a real war, where the total power of the nation...
was committed to total and unconditional defeat of the enemy.
And their outlook on the war was a lot different.
It would only last a couple of weeks.
But this thing was an ongoing story.
And more and more Americans are getting killed now.
The leadership, you know, the President of the United States, Commander-in-Chief of all the military, the boss doesn't know what he wants to do.
So at least they're uncertain in the rank.
The soldiers are doing the best job that they can.
Every time they catch Charlie, they twist his tail.
They really go after him.
Charlie is a euphemistic expression for the enemy.
And... We've studied a lot about the leadership and the problems, such as the one-year tour of duty doesn't give you much time to learn your manner.
Make...
attachments with your troops?
Or, or get you acquainted with the surroundings?
Do you agree with that?
Well, that's a theory.
It said the Vien- American didn't have ten years experience in Vietnam and had one years experience ten times, yeah.
But that's not true because amongst the non-commissioned officers and amongst the officer corps, most of these guys were careerists.
It wasn't like in World War II where a guy had just been drafted.
Most of the, uh,
non-commissioned officers, sergeants, and officers that I served with had been in the Army before Vietnam started.
So these guys were committed towards the military service.
Number two, it doesn't take you a whole lot of time to get to know 40 guys or 100 guys or who's ever working for you, especially if they're also professional soldiers and good soldiers.
I can say that the men that served under me and the people that I served were all professionals.
whether they had been in the army for six months or 16 years, there'd be no difference.
They did their job very, very well as they were trained to do.
Should the tours of duty over there have been longer?

No, I think considering the fact that there wasn't very much popular support at home for the war, it would have been really hard to stay over there indefinitely until you got killed and wounded to the point they had to be evacuated, so it was nice to have something to look forward to getting out of there for a while because that
You know, it's not like World War II where you're getting all these great letters from home and everybody's proud of you and all that stuff.
People at home didn't know what the hell was going on.
All they got was a distorted picture from the media.
So they were worried.
You were worried about your folks at home.
You were worried about yourself.
Gee, you know, the government's so uncertain about what's going on here.
I don't want to get killed for nothing.
But you still try to do your job.
So should we have just stayed over there forever and ever and ever like in World War II?
No.
I don't think so.
I don't think it would be a good idea.
The war was pretty simple.
There wasn't a whole lot of sophistication to it.
What you tried to do over in Vietnam was kill the bad guys.
That was it.
That was the job.
We had the ground.
We had the terrain to belong to us.
They were the interlopers.
All they had to do was find them and kill them.
It was hard to find them, though, wasn't it?
Pretty sneaky, yeah.
tunnels and jungles, and sometimes they disguised themselves to be civilians.
What a surprise.
So, so it wasn't a terribly sophisticated, well, like in a communications standpoint, everybody talked about radio.
Yeah, didn't the United States spend a lot of money on sophisticated equipment and smart bombs and little devices that would sense a person that looked like the IBM computers?
Didn't they map on those?
Yeah, sure, but
I mean, we were using that technology in places other than Vietnam, too.
We used like those sensor devices, which were highly classified.
They were used in Czechoslovakia to monitor, they were dropped over Europe to detect Russian troop movements and all that kind of stuff.
It's what they call an unintended ground sensor, and all it does is, it's like a little seismographic.
Something goes past it, it gives us a signal thing, and the skies look like little bushes and little trees and stuff.
I mean, that's, that's a little gadgets, but the, and all of this is giving information that somebody's walking past, whether it's a water buffalo or a platoon of Viet Cong, you don't know.
So you, yeah, there was a lot of tech, like the M16 being a high-tech weapon, right?
It was made out of plastic and it had die-cast parts and a tiny little high-velocity bullet, but it, you know, it's still a lagoon that shoots people.
Ain't no different than something Napoleon had.
So...
But it wasn't a terribly sophisticated war.
The whole trick was to find out where the bad guys were and then smoke them.
Kill them.
That's all.
You mentioned the career soldier a lot.
I'm sorry.
Yeah.
But in a lot of the books we've read, they mention that a lifer was this worst kind of soldier.
to lead you because of the careerism and the attitudes of, to be selfish motives when you're leading your men.
Did you experience any of that?
Did you see that?
Yeah, some of the guys would say, oh, you're a lifer.
I'd say, yeah, sure, I'm a lifer.
If you want to say a lifer, I'm a professional soldier.
It's my job.
My return was, would you like to be taken, led into combat by an amateur or professional?
But some career soldiers, did you ever see them making totally selfish moves?
Some of the books we read, they wouldn't tell their men about the Viet Cong waiting or the camp because they wanted them to be extra alert and they didn't want them to maybe shy away from the camp.
No, I didn't see any of that.
A bad leader, did you ever see that?
Oh, sure.
Not just a stupid one, but someone with the wrong motives.
No, no, no.
No, I didn't say that.
I saw a lot of bad leaders in the sense that leadership is a technical and a personal attribute.
You have to have no technical things.
You have to know how to lead.
How do you maneuver a company?
How do you maneuver a battalion?
How do you plan a military operation?
Yeah, to be a leader you have to have some technical training.
Then you have to have personal characteristics that are very important.
Some guys had it more than others.
They were good leaders and bad leaders.
You have good brain surgeons and bad surgeons.
You have good college professors and you have not so good college professors, right?
That's just a human trait.
It has nothing to do with being a soldier.
And if you weren't good at what you did, you didn't do it for very long.
The boss would find somebody else to do it.

You take a simple job like a guy whose responsibility was to be a platoon leader, and he went out and he did something wrong, when he should have been able to figure out how to do it correctly, he was usually sent back and he was in charge of the mesh kit repair company or something.
Or some guy who was reluctant to take, to lead his men properly, he was relieved that somebody else was put in there.
Senator, you don't see careerism as a major problem?
Well, what do you mean by careerism?
Careerism as... Let's make the most of this situation because it's the only war we've got.
Yeah, I think as a professional soldier, they all thought about the impact that this conflict or war would have on their career.
You have to think about that.
Well, for example, there was a passage in a book...
I think you want to do well, though.
Because if you do poorly, it's going to screw up your career.
So you want to do well.

Okay, there was a passage in our book about one military leader who, he was so set on having a high body count of Vietnamese that when the medevac came in, instead of putting his wounded on, he wanted to put the dead Vietnamese on.
I mean, did you ever see him?
Never, ever.
Never saw anything like that.
I saw a guy's,
commanding officers who would bend over backwards to do things for their men.
Like get them extra chow or get into new weapons.
When they new weapons came out, they want to get it first or to get them a three-day break somewhere or an extra R&R.
I'm talking about those guys that really busted their buns for their soldiers.
I saw that more than I saw nonsense like you're talking about.
I don't know who reported that, but I've never seen anything like that.
How about fragging?
No, none of that went on when I was there.
That was later on when America pulled back from the combat role and the guys were just sitting around the barracks and had nothing to do.
The drugs were a big problem later on too.
Did you see him when you were there?

Yeah, I'd be out in the jungle in a fire base or something and one of my soldiers would come walking by and he's got a bag of marijuana and he had a big enough choke of horse and I said, what the hell do you got there?
He says, he just bought it from the mama sign over here.
I said, what'd you give for it?
He says, a couple of peas, like $2 for a pound of local wheat.
He says, you're not going to, all right, dump it out, man.
Oh, come on, Captain.
I said, dump it out.
And usually guys who did that were real zorches anyway.
I mean, this is a guy who, his job in the battalion was to go around and burn the cans of shit.
And so we got rid of the, some yo-ho like that, some rum diddy and a goo-goo wasn't worth anything.
He'd have a job like that.
No, and, uh, fragging?
Nah, I didn't see that.
There was not one, one instance of that.
And it really is hilarious in that movie, the platoon had us two sergeants, one was trying to kill the other.
You never saw that.
You know, later on, in, uh, I guess in the early 70s, it started having a lot of fragging incidents, and I heard about that.
Who was doing it?
These were the guys...
They were, they really weren't soldiers.
They were just civilians who were there against their will and they just were rebelling against the symbol of authority and they were petty anyway.
They'd throw a hand grenade under a sleeping lieutenant.
I mean, that takes a lot of guts to do that.
Those guys are never soldiers.
A soldier would never do that.
A real soldier would never do that.
Speaking of soldiers, what did you think about the armed forces?
I didn't see a whole lot of it, but they were okay individually.
They weren't, they weren't as good as Americans.
They weren't as good, they weren't as highly motivated.
Believe it or not, they were fighting for their own country.
We were, but the American soldier was a better motivated combat soldier than some of the Arlins I saw.
Now a good buddy of mine advised a
was a signal advisor to an Arvin division, and I went over to see him, and he said, what is the kind of hair you got here?
These guys are a little loose.
Because American soldiers were, believe it or not, forget all the Hollywood movies, pretty well organized, pretty well structured.
They could do something.
You snap your fingers and you can get 24,000 guys to move in one direction at one time.
The Arvins were just a little goofy-looky about that.
They were just...
And I don't know is if it's as much an Arvin problem or it's just a cultural problem with all of that part of the world.
The North Vietnamese were not supermen either.
They kind of goofed up a few times, so.
So I think, did I have a lot of contact with the Arvins?
No.
Did I see them?
Did you ever fight with them?
No, no, no.
They, sometimes like we got hit one night and
We were 150 soldiers with three tubes of 105 millimeter artillery.
We got hit by a North Vietnamese regiment of about a thousand.
We fought all night and we just, it was a hell of a battle.
And then that morning when the sun came up, an ARVN unit came in to sweep the jungle to flush out any wounded or anything like that.
But you know, they were okay.
They were alright.
You know, a lot of those Army soldiers were guys that, until they became a soldier, couldn't read or write.
They went out in the boondocks working on a rice field.
A lot of Saigon cowboys, I wonder how they avoided the draft.
And a lot of people in America avoided the draft, too, for some reason.
Do you have any combat experiences you'd like to talk about?
Any particular...
horrifying ones, or ones that stand out as, did you ever feel like you were a hero?
No, no, you don't.
It's a son of a bitch to get shot at.
I see friends blowing up.
I see a lieutenant, but he's riding in a jeep, and he was just heading out of a fire base, and a remote-controlled bomb went off under his butt and blew him to a million pieces.
Nice young fellow.
Cut him right in the hand.
I was sitting on top of a bunker out in a dried-out rice field with another captain, and he and I were smoking Kent cigarettes.
And the only tree in the whole area was the one we were sitting under, and a sniper opened up on it.
And it was the only casualty I sustained in the Vietnam War.
What happened?
Well, the bullets went right over the top.
The guy was firing an AK-47, and he wasn't a very good shot.
He wasn't an American marksman, that's for sure.
He cut loose at all 30 rounds and went over our heads.
Because I remember the leaves coming down as the bullets popped through the tree.
And this captain and I immediately fell forward.
And as I fell forward, the cigarette broke off and the hot end of it went up my nose.
Oh, that really got me angry.
Boy, that hurt like hell.
If you don't think a hot cigarette up your nose doesn't hurt.
And I knew where the bullets were coming from, you could tell.
So I went over there with a .50 caliber machine gun.
I cranked it and they fired one round and the gun jammed.
I picked up an M16, fired one round, and that damn thing jammed.
So I grabbed my .45 out, fired one round, and that damn thing jammed.
I threw the .45 down, sat down, lit up another second, said, the hell with it, you can go home.
So you didn't kill him?
No, I sent a bunch of guys, they go out that wood line, they found a stack of empty brass that was still warm.
That was it.
They brought the brass back in a hat.
In contrast to seeing your friends die, how did you feel when you killed...
When I killed somebody, I never killed anybody.
You never killed anyone?
Mm-hmm.
How's that?
Doing my job.
I was a signal launcher.
So you were never out there in the field fighting?
Yeah, mm-hmm.
But it's not like you and I sitting in this room, we would smoke.
Never did that.
In fact, very few guys ever did that.
Very rarely did that happen.
And I saw a lot of dead North Vietnamese, hundreds and hundreds, and I didn't know that our boys had killed.
But I never pulled a trigger on myself.
A captain
It's not my job to go out there and stick a bayonet in somebody.
Do you think you'd have a different attitude now if you had actually killed people?
Well, see, when you say kill, I pull out a gun and shoot you, that's killing.
I get on the radio and call an airstrike and there's two tons of napalm on it.
That's a little distant.
So yeah, I guess I've been responsible for the death of people over there.
But if they had stayed home in North Vietnam,
they wouldn't have gotten into trouble.
Do I feel bad about it?
No.
What about the innocent South Vietnamese?
War's hard.
War's really tough, you know.
People get killed in the war.
I don't feel any worse about that than the fact that we took out Hiroshima, Nagasaki, Dresden, Hamburg.
You know, in Hamburg, thousands and thousands of civilians perished in bomb shelters and firestorms.
You know how they died?
It melted, the intense heat.
Now do I feel bad about that?
Sure I feel bad about anybody getting killed.
But that's what war is all about.
That's what war is all about.
Okay, um... That's why you should never undertake a war.
Halfway.
Halfway, precisely.
So would you say that was our problem with the war, is that we didn't commit fully?
Yeah.
Not the leadership or the conventional versus guerrilla?
I don't know how I can make this point clear.
But life in America during the Vietnam War was damn good in America.
There's cars, there's plenty of cars and everybody was, we had TVs and plenty of work and making good money.
Wow, life is great.
Lots of leisure time, terrific vacations.
The dollar was king, you know, four marks to the dollar in Europe.
Life in America was good except for one little thing.
Every so often, somebody you knew came home in an aluminum coffin.
It's almost as if the price of the prosperity that America enjoyed during the Johnson years, the Great Society, it's almost as if the price for that was paid with blood in Vietnam.
I've got a suspicion about that.
I'm not entirely sure that that's correct, but I got a sneaky feeling that

that quality of life and the great social programs that Johnson put into effect during the real big bill in Vietnam was not paid for with the blood of American lions in the jungles and the ice fields of South Africa.
Now, that'd be something for you to take a look at.
Everybody thinks about Johnson as the Vietnam president, but he was a great society.
He was the New Deal phase two.
He's going to pick up where FDR left off.
He's a protege to Franklin Delano Roosevelt.
And he saw this as his golden opportunity to really make a difference in American life.
And that damn Flanagan, that was to be a non-war, but I think that's what paid.
What?
For the first break.
Deemployment, you know.
Oh, so you think that... You think that can of C-rations got to the American soldier in a foxhole free?
No, somebody had to pay for it and put it there.
Somebody had to put it in a little tin can and put it in a box and then ship it.
A war is a great builder of prosperity at home.
Look at World War II.
The depression in America didn't end until World War II started.

I got a funny feeling that if some historian were to take a hard look at it, maybe you're going to take a historian and a sociologist who have been studying the society from an analytical standpoint, that
The war in Vietnam created greatly to the prosperity that America enjoyed during the same period of time that the war was going on.
Got a funny feeling about that.
Um, if you, do you have, would you like to add anything else or can, I'd like to ask you about how and why you came home.
Well I came home because my wife got real sick.
And the Red Cross, I was due to come home in January, I got a call in December saying to get home.
Red Cross and Telegram.
It was right after you were born.
Right after you were born.
And Mama got sick, she had a problem and the Red Cross said to get her home.
So I left a month early, after 11 months.
I was out of combat for all intents and purposes though because I was back at the division headquarters and I was a radio systems engineer.
That's a fancy job for a guy who just fooled around radio.
I was a staff officer then.
I spent nine months in combat and two months behind a desk.
I got the telegram at 8.30 in the morning and at one o'clock I was gone.
I packed my bags and I left all my gear there.
I took one suitcase and that vase up there, see that vase in the middle?
That's from a Buddhist temple in Saigon that the tanks were gonna crush.
It's a beautiful vase.
That's the only souvenir I brought home.
I took about 20 pictures in a year somewhere, I don't know where they are.
I came home, not by any organized means.
I came, I was wearing my jungle fatigues, all dirty and everything.
Even though I was a desk officer, it was hot and everything.
Got on a helicopter to Town Center Air Base.
Grabbed a cargo plane from Town Center to the Philippines.
Sat in a chair for 24 hours at Clark Air Force Base in the Philippines and grabbed a commercial flight to Hawaii.
I remember getting off the plane at Hawaii, 8.30 in the morning.
And I'm still in the same closet I've been wearing for three days now.
Got a beard and everything.
Going to a coffee shop.
in the airport and all these civilians looked at me like I wasn't there, like I was invisible.

I sat at the counter in a coffee shop with all these ladies with their blue hair and their muumuu's and their flowers and they're lazy getting ready to go back to their states after a beautiful Hawaiian vacation, like there wasn't even a war on.
That hurt you?
No, it didn't hurt me, it just made me realize that most civilians didn't care.
As long as the war didn't affect them personally, they didn't really care about it.
I'm sitting there in the coffee shop and everybody's eating their pancakes and their fresh pineapple and it was gorgeous, a beautiful coffee shop in the airport.
And I said to the waitress, I said, look, it's 8.30 in the morning, I'm just coming back from Vietnam.
Can I please have two boilermakers?
I'd say a glass of beer and a double shot of whiskey.
She says, Captain, you got it.
And I slept on a plane from Hawaii back to the States, got into San Francisco, and that plane from Hawaii to San Francisco was continuing on with the same flight crew to New York.
And the stewardess said, God bless him, they had seen a lot of guys coming.
They put me in the plane there, and they covered me up with blankets and everything, and they gave me a two-steak dinner.
They gave me a couple of shots of bourbon, and I said, we'll wake you up when we get to New York, because I was pretty whacked out by
The plane was empty.
And these are the same students that have been shuttling guys all back and across the Pacific now for years.
And I wonder what those students could have to say about how many guys they took and how many guys they brought back and what the difference was.
I wonder what that had.
I don't know what they thought.
After I got back to New York, that was the biggest surprise of my life.
I got off the plane at JFK or LaGuardia, I forget which one it was.
LaGuardia Airport.
Yeah.
It's like 6.30 in the morning and all these businessmen are catching a shuttle flight to D.C. and stuff like that.
Here I'm getting off the plane in jungle fatigues.
And it's cold in New York in December.
And these guys don't even see me.
Not one of them came up to me and said, hey, thanks for what you're doing.
Just like they didn't even want to acknowledge the fact that I was there.
I felt pretty low.
Then did that hurt?
Wow, that hurt, you know.

See all these very nicely dressed businessmen with their suits and their camo hair coats and their briefcases and their shiny shoes, going about their business, because that's what all the shuttle flights leave out.
Going to Boston, going to Philly, going to DC.
All these businessmen and not one person came over to me or even, even as I passed them,
So I went in the bathroom, it was kind of early, the bathroom at the airport, and I cleaned up.
I washed a little bit and shaved, and I had some civilian clothes in my suitcase.
I put those on because I didn't want my wife to see me in my dirty old fatigues, all smelly and nasty.
And I grabbed the cab to the apartment, and the Puerto Rican cab driver, and I had to give him directions.
Nice guy.
He didn't say anything to me either because he didn't know who the hell I was.
I got to the apartment and my wife wasn't there.
She had gone to the bakery to get some, but my mother-in-law was there, her pop, she was there.
And oh my God, she was so happy to see me.
They were all relieved.
And then mommy came up and she was feeling pretty sick, but I could tell she was enormously relieved.
But she had had a baby while I was gone.
And we had fresh bread and real coffee and sat in the kitchen.
We didn't talk about the war over there.
We just talked about the family catching up on all that stuff.
There was not much of a homecoming.
My family was happy to see me.
I remember seeing Jennifer when I left her.
She was a tiny little baby, three, four months old, and now she was wearing dresses and had long hair, and it was really quite exciting.
Then later on that afternoon, my folks came from Staten Island to Queens with my other daughter.
I didn't see her as tiny.
I think about three or four months old.
It's like, what went through my mind was all that was behind me now.
Do you think that your life, how do you think Vietnam changed you as a person?
Not at all.
Not at all?
No.
See, I was a professional soldier.
When I spent eleven years in the Army, and Vietnam was only one tenth of that, roughly ten percent of my military service was spent in Vietnam.
I think what had more impact upon my life was
leadership school when I was making OCS.
I think being a father had more impact on my life than being a Vietnam soldier.
Did you feel like people didn't understand you or couldn't relate to you or what you'd experienced?
No, I didn't expect any civilian to understand what a soldier's been through has been a combat.
No civilian could understand it.
So I didn't feel special.
Did you feel foreign to people?
Like you couldn't, did you feel like you had changed at all to where people...
I was the same guy I was when I went there.
No, it had no effect.
And that's another thing, I see all these guys who were traumatized by the Vietnam experiences.
I wonder if they're really being sincere about that.
I'm sure some of them are because there's always people that are traumatized by the horror of war.
But I don't think those fellows are any different than the guys in World War II or in Korea or the Spanish-American War or the Civil War.
I mean, yeah, war's a nasty thing, but you tend to put those things behind you.
And, you know, the vast majority of the guys that went to Vietnam...
